title: Wells' Criteria for Pulmonary Embolism
description: Clinical pretest probability score for pulmonary embolism based on seven bedside criteria; supports both 3-tier (low/intermediate/high) and 2-tier (PE unlikely/likely) interpretations to guide D-dimer testing and imaging decisions

parameters.name: clinical_signs_dvt
parameters.description: Clinical signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (e.g., unilateral leg swelling and pain with palpation of the deep veins)

parameters.name: pe_most_likely
parameters.description: Pulmonary embolism is the most likely diagnosis (alternative diagnosis less likely than PE)

parameters.name: heart_rate_over_100
parameters.description: Heart rate greater than 100 beats per minute

parameters.name: immobilization_surgery_recent
parameters.description: Immobilization for ≥3 days or surgery within the previous 4 weeks

parameters.name: previous_dvt_pe
parameters.description: Previous history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism

parameters.name: active_malignancy
parameters.description: Active cancer (treatment ongoing, within 6 months, or palliative)

ranges.interpretation: Low pretest probability. Recommend D-dimer testing; if negative, PE is effectively ruled out; if positive, proceed to imaging (CT pulmonary angiography).
Intermediate pretest probability. D-dimer testing recommended; if negative, PE unlikely; if positive, CT pulmonary angiography recommended. Consider clinical context.
High pretest probability. Proceed directly to imaging (CT pulmonary angiography). D-dimer testing is not necessary. Consider empiric anticoagulation if bleeding risk is low while awaiting imaging.

references: Wells PS, Anderson DR, Rodger M, et al. Excluding pulmonary embolism at the bedside without diagnostic imaging: management of patients with suspected pulmonary embolism presenting to the emergency department by using a simple clinical model and D-dimer. Ann Intern Med. 2001;135(2):98-107.

van Belle A, Büller HR, Huisman MV, et al. Effectiveness of managing suspected pulmonary embolism using an algorithm combining clinical probability, D-dimer testing, and computed tomography. JAMA. 2006;295(2):172-179.
Konstantinides SV, Meyer G, Becattini C, et al. 2019 ESC Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of acute pulmonary embolism. Eur Heart J. 2020;41(4):543-603.
formula: Score = Clinical signs of DVT (3.0) + PE most likely diagnosis (3.0) + Heart rate >100 bpm (1.5) + Immobilization ≥3 days or surgery within 4 weeks (1.5) + Previous DVT/PE (1.5) + Hemoptysis (1.0) + Active malignancy (1.0)
notes: Two validated interpretations exist: 3-tier (low 0-1; intermediate 2-6; high ≥6.5) and 2-tier (PE unlikely ≤4; PE likely >4).
The 'PE most likely' item is subjective and may reduce inter-observer reliability; consider using Geneva score for a fully objective alternative.
Intended for hemodynamically stable outpatients and ED settings; not validated in pregnancy or inpatients.
Use D-dimer to safely exclude PE in low or intermediate probability patients; proceed directly to imaging in high probability patients.
Consider age-adjusted D-dimer thresholds in patients >50 years.
